bringing dinosaurs back to life you all know the story right I mean I assume everyone here has seen Jurassic Park if you want to make a dinosaur you go out you find yourself a piece of petrified tree sap otherwise known as Amber that has some blood sucking insects in it good ones and you get your insect you drill into it and you suck out some DNA because obviously all insects that suck blood in those days suck dinosaur DNA out and and you take your DNA back to the laboratory and you clone it and I guess you inject it into maybe an ostrich or something like that and then you wait and lo and behold out pops a little baby dinosaur and everybody's happy about that and they're happy over and over again they keep doing it they just keep making these things and and then they then then and then you know then the dinosaurs being social act out their socialness and they get together and they conspire and of course that's what makes Steven Spielberg's movie conspiring dinosaurs chasing people around so I assume everybody knows that if you actually had a piece of Amber and it had an insect in it and you drilled into it and you got something out of that insect and you cloned it and you did it over and over and over again you'd have a room full of mosquitoes right or maybe and probably a whole bunch of trees as well now if you want dinosaur DNA I say go to the dinosaur so that's what we've done back in 1993 when the movie came out we actually had a grant from the National Science Foundation to attempt to extract DNA from a dinosaur and we chose the dinosaur on the left a Tyrannosaurus Rex which was a very nice specimen and one of my former doctoral students Dr Mary schwitzer actually had the background to do this sort of thing and so she looked into the bone of this T-Rex one of the thigh bones and she actually found some very interesting structures in there they found these red circular looking objects and they looked for all the world like red blood cells and they're in what appear to be the blood channels that go through the bone and so she thought well what the heck so she sampled some material out of it and it wasn't DNA she didn't find DNA but she did find he which is the biological Foundation of hemoglobin and that was really cool that was interesting I that was here we have 65 milliony old he well we tried and tried and we couldn't really get anything else out of it so a few years went by and then we started the hell Creek project and the hell Creek project was this massive undertaking to get as many dinosaurs as we could possibly find and hopefully find some dinosaurs that had more material in them and out in eastern Montana there's a a lot of space a lot of bad lands and not very many people and so you can go out there and find a lot of stuff and we did find a lot of stuff we found a lot of Tyrannosaurs but we found one special Tyrannosaur and we called it B rex and B rex was found under a th000 cubic yards of rock it wasn't a very complete T-Rex and it wasn't a very big T-Rex but it was a very special BX I and my colleagues cut into it and we were able to determine by looking at lines of Arrested growth some lines in it that b rex had died at the age of 16 we don't really know how long dinosaurs Liv because we haven't found the oldest one yet but this one died at the age of 16 we gave samples to Mary schwitzer and she was actually able to determine that b rex was a female based on medular tissue found on the inside of the bone medular tissue is the calcium buildup the calcium storage basically when an animal is pregnant when a bird is pregnant so here was a character that linked birds and dinosaurs but Mary went further she took the bone and she dumped it into acid now we all know that bones are fossilized and so if you dump it into acid there shouldn't be anything left but there was something left there were blood vessels left there were flexible clear blood vessels and so here was the first soft tissues from a dinosaur was extraordinary but she also found osteocytes which are the cells that laid down the bones and try and try we could not find DNA but she did find find evidence of proteins but we thought maybe well we thought maybe that the material was breaking down after it was coming out of the ground we thought maybe it was deteriorating very fast and so we built a laboratory in the back of an 18 wheeler trailer actually took the laboratory to the field where we could get better samples and we did we got better material uh the cells looked better the vessels looked better found the protein collagen I mean it it was wonderful stuff but it's not dinosaur DNA so we have discovered that dinosaur DNA all DNA just breaks down too fast we're just not going to be able to do what they did in Jurassic Park we're not going to be able to make a dinosaur based on a dinosaur but birds are dinosaurs birds are living dinosaurs we actually classify them as dinosaurs We Now call them non-avian dinosaurs and Aven dinosaurs so the non-avian dinosaurs are the big clunky ones that went extinct Aven dinosaurs are our modern birds so we don't have to make a dinosaur so I already have [Music] them I know you're you're you're as bad as the sixth graders right the sixth graders look at it and they say no you can call it you can call it a dinosaur but look at the Velociraptor the Velociraptor is cool the chicken is not so this is our problem as you can imagine the chicken is a dinosaur I mean it really is I mean you you can't argue with it because we you know we're the classifiers and we've classified it that way but the sixth graders demand it fix the chicken so so that's what I'm here to tell you about how we're going to fix a chicken so we have a number of of ways that we actually can fix the because Evolution works we actually have some evolutionary tools we'll call them biological modification tools we have selection and we know selection works right I mean we started out with a wolf-like creature and we end up with a malti I mean that's that's that's definitely genetic modification or any of the other funny looking little dogs we also have trans Genesis trans Genesis is really cool too that's where you take a gene out of one animal and stick it in another one that's how we you know that's how people made glowfish you take a jean a glow Jean out of a out of a coral or a or a jellyfish and you stick it in a zebra fish and they glow and you know that's pretty cool and they obviously make a lot of money off of them and now they're you know they're making glow rabbits and and glow all sorts of things and I guess we could make a glow chicken but I don't think that'll satisfy the six graders either but there's another thing there's what we call adamism activation and adamism activation is basically an atavism is a is an ancestral characteristic now you've you've heard that occasionally children are born with tals and it's because it's a an ancestral characteristic and so there are a number of atavisms that can happen snakes are occasionally born with legs and here's an example this is a chicken with teeth a fellow by the name of Matthew Harris at the University of Wisconsin in Madison actually figured out a way to stimulate the gene of teeth for teeth and so was able to actually turn the tooth gene on and produce teeth in in chickens which now that's a good characteristic we can we can save that one all right we we know we can use that we can make a chicken with teeth that's getting closer that's better than a glowwing chicken a friend of mine a a colleague of mine Dr Hans Larsson at McGill University is actually looking at adisms and he's looking at them by looking at the embryogenesis of birds and actually looking at how they develop and he's interested in how birds actually lost their tail he's also interested in the transformation of the arm the hand to the wing he's looking for those genes as well and I said well you know if you can find those I can just reverse them and make what I need to make for the sixth graders and so he agreed and so that's what we're looking into if you look at dinosaur hands a velociraptor has that cool looking hand with the claws on it archaeopteris which is a bird a primitive bird still has that very primitive hand but as you can see the pigeon or a chicken or anything else like a bird has kind of a weird looking hand because the hand is a wing but the cool thing is is that if you look in the embryo as the embryo is developing the hand actually looks pretty much like the arch opter hand it has the three fingers the three digits but a gene turns on that actually fuses those together and so what we're looking for is that Gene we want to stop that Gene from turning on fusing those hands together so we can get a chicken that hatches out with a three-fingered hand like the archaeopteris and the same goes for the Tails birds have basically rudimentary tails and so we know that in Embry as the animal is developing it actually has a relatively long tail but a gene turns on and resorbs the tail gets rid of it so that's the other Gene we're looking for we want to stop that tail from resorbing so what we're trying to do really is take our chicken modify it and make a chickenosaurus it's a cooler looking chicken I mean but it's just the very Basics so **Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How did Dr. Mary H. Schweitzer find the blood vessels in the dinosaur bones?
Options: A. She used a scanning electron microscope, B. She cut thin slices of bone and compared them to MRI scans of birds, C. She didn't, D. She dumped them into acid
Correct Option: D

Question 2: What is the speaker's approach to learning due to being dyslexic? Options: A. Reading extensively on various subjects., B. Practicing and finding things through hands-on experience., C. Watching documentaries and videos., D. Listening to podcasts and audiobooks. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What did the speaker and his colleagues discover about dinosaur behavior? Options: A. Dinosaurs were solitary animals and only came together to mate., B. Dinosaurs built nests, lived in colonies, and cared for their young., C. Dinosaurs were strictly carnivores and hunted alone., D. Dinosaurs were herbivores and lived in small family groups. Correct Option: None

A project to find and excavate dinosaur fossils in eastern Montana., D. A project to study the geology of the Hell Creek formation. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What did Mary Schwitzer discover in the bone of a T-Rex? Options: A. DNA molecules that could be used for cloning., B. Red blood cells and evidence of hemoglobin., C. A fully intact dinosaur embryo., D. A piece of fossilized skin with feathers. Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why is it impossible to extract DNA from dinosaur fossils? Options: A. Because DNA molecules are too small to be detected., B. Because DNA breaks down too quickly over time., C. Because DNA is not preserved in fossilized bones., D. Because DNA is too complex to be extracted. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What are "non-avian dinosaurs" and "avian dinosaurs"? Options: A. Non-avian dinosaurs are birds, while avian dinosaurs are reptiles., B. Non-avian dinosaurs are reptiles, while avian dinosaurs are birds., C. Non-avian dinosaurs are carnivores, while avian dinosaurs are herbivores., D. Non-avian dinosaurs are herbivores, while avian dinosaurs are carnivores. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the goal of the speaker's project to "fix a chicken"? Options: A. To genetically engineer a chicken to have teeth and a long tail., B. To breed a chicken that can fly like a dinosaur., C. To create a chicken that looks like a Velociraptor., D. To make a chicken that can lay dinosaur-sized eggs. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is "atavism activation"? Options: A. A process of genetically engineering an organism to have a new trait., B. A process of activating an ancestral characteristic in an organism., C. A process of cloning an extinct species., D. A process of creating a hybrid organism. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the potential benefit of the speaker's project to "fix a chicken"? Options: A. To create a new species of dinosaur., B. To improve the taste and quality of chicken meat., C. To teach kids about evolutionary biology and developmental biology., D. To create a new form of entertainment. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say that if walls could talk,
each building would have a story to tell, but few would tell so many fascinating
stories in so many different voices as the Hagia Sophia, or holy wisdom. Perched at the crossroads 
of continents and cultures, it has seen massive changes 
from the name of the city where it stands, to its own structure and purpose. And today, the elements
from each era stand ready to tell their tales 
to any visitor who will listen. Even before you arrive at the Hagia Sophia,
the ancient fortifications hint at the strategic importance 
of the surrounding city, founded as Byzantium 
by Greek colonists in 657 BCE. And successfully renamed as 
Augusta Antonia, New Rome and Constantinople as it was conquered, reconquered,
destroyed and rebuilt by various Greek, Persian and 
Roman rulers over the following centuries. And it was within these walls that 
the first Megale Ekklesia, or great church, was built in the fourth century. Though it was soon burned
to the ground in riots, it established the location for
the region's main religious structure for centuries to come. Near the entrance,
the marble stones with reliefs are the last reminders 
of the second church. Built in 415 CE, it was destroyed 
during the Nika Riots of 532 when angry crowds at a chariot race nearly overthrew the emperor, 
Justinian the First. Having barely managed to retain power, he resolved to rebuild the church
on a grander scale, and five years later, the edifice 
you see before you was completed. As you step inside, the stones 
of the foundation and walls murmur tales from their homelands
of Egypt and Syria, while columns taken from the Temple
of Artemis recall a more ancient past. Runic inscriptions carved by the 
Vikings of the emperor's elite guard carry the lore of distant northern lands. But your attention is caught by 
the grand dome, representing the heavens. Reaching over 50 meters high and 
over 30 meters in diameter and ringed by windows around its base, the golden dome appears
suspended from heaven, light reflecting through its interior. Beneath its grandiose symbolism,
the sturdy reinforcing Corinthian columns, brought from Lebanon after 
the original dome was partially destroyed by an earthquake in 558 CE, quietly remind you of its fragility and the engineering skills
such a marvel requires. If a picture is worth a thousand words, the mosaics from the next several 
centuries have the most to say not only about their Biblical themes, but also the Byzantine emperors who commissioned them, often depicted along with Christ. But beneath their loud and clear voices, one hears the haunting echoes of 
the damaged and missing mosaics and icons, desecrated and looted during 
the Latin Occupation in the Fourth Crusade. Within the floor, the tomb inscription
of Enrico Dandolo, the Venetian ruler who 
commanded the campaign, is a stark reminder of those 57 years that Hagia Sophia spent as a Roman Catholic church before returning to its orthodox roots
upon the Byzantine Reconquest. But it would not remain a church for long. Weakened by the Crusades, Constantinople
fell to the Ottomans in 1453 and would be known as Istanbul thereafter. After allowing his soldiers
three days of pillage, Sultan Mehmed the Second 
entered the building. Though heavily damaged, 
its grandeur was not lost on the young sultan who immediately
rededicated it to Allah, proclaiming that it would be
the new imperial mosque. The four minarets built 
over the next century are the most obvious sign of this era, serving as architectural supports 
in addition to their religious purpose. But there are many others. Ornate candle holders relate 
Suleiman's conquest of Hungary, while giant caligraphy discs 
hung from the ceiling remind visitors for the first 
four caliphs who followed Muhammad. Though the building you see today still
looks like a mosque, it is now a museum, a decision made in 1935 by Kemal Ataturk, the modernizing first president of Turkey following the Ottoman Empire's collapse. It was this secularization
that allowed for removal of the carpets hiding 
the marble floor decorations and the plaster covering 
the Christian mosaics. Ongoing restoration work 
has allowed the multiplicity of voices in Hagia Sophia's long history to be heard again after
centuries of silence. But conflict remains. Hidden mosaics cry out from 
beneath Islamic calligraphy, valuable pieces of history that cannot be
uncovered without destroying others. Meanwhile, calls sound from
both Muslim and Christian communities to return the building to 
its former religious purposes. The story of the divine wisdom 
may be far from over, but one can only hope that 
the many voices residing there will be able to tell their part
for years to come.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: During the 4th crusade of the Latin Occupation ________.
Options: A. The city became known as Istanbul, B. The dome of the Hagia Sophia collapsed during and earthquake, C. Many mosaics were looted or destroyed, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What does the name "Hagia Sophia" mean? Options: A. Holy Church, B. Divine Wisdom, C. Great Mosque, D. Ancient Temple Correct Option: None
Question 2: In what year was the city where Hagia Sophia stands founded by Greek colonists? Options: A. 657 CE, B. 657 BCE, C. 415 CE, D. 532 CE Correct Option: None
Question 3: What event led to the destruction of the second church built on the site of Hagia Sophia? Options: A. The Nika Riots of 532 CE, B. The Latin Occupation in the Fourth Crusade, C. The Ottoman conquest of Constantinople, D. An earthquake in 558 CE Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is unique about the grand dome of Hagia Sophia? Options: A. It is the largest dome in the world, B. It is made of solid gold, C. It appears suspended from heaven due to the windows around its base, D. It is supported by a single column Correct Option: None
Question 5: What type of columns were used to reinforce the dome after it was partially destroyed by an earthquake? Options: A. Corinthian columns, B. Doric columns, C. Ionic columns, D. Roman columns Correct Option: None
Question 6: What event led to the desecration and looting of the mosaics and icons in Hagia Sophia? Options: A. The Latin Occupation in the Fourth Crusade, B. The Ottoman conquest of Constantinople, C. The Byzantine Reconquest, D. The earthquake in 558 CE Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who rededicated Hagia Sophia as a mosque after the Ottoman conquest of Constantinople? Options: A. Sultan Mehmed the Second, B. Kemal Ataturk, C. Justinian the First, D. Enrico Dandolo Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the current status of Hagia Sophia? Options: A. It is a functioning mosque, B. It is a functioning church, C. It is a museum, D. It is a historical ruin Correct Option: None
Question 9: Who made the decision to secularize Hagia Sophia and convert it into a museum? Options: A. Sultan Mehmed the Second, B. Kemal Ataturk, C. Justinian the First, D. Enrico Dandolo Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the ongoing conflict regarding Hagia Sophia? Options: A. Whether to restore the building to its original state, B. Whether to return the building to its former religious purposes, C. Whether to allow visitors to enter the building, D. Whether to rename the building Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What event led to the desecration and looting of the mosaics and icons in Hagia Sophia? 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the event that led to the damage or destruction of the mosaics in Hagia Sophia. The correct option for Question 6 is A. The Latin Occupation in the Fourth Crusade, which matches the correct option for the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6.

Correct Option: B

the first Megale Ekklesia, or great church, was built in the fourth century. Though it was soon burned
to the ground in riots, it established the location for

the marble stones with reliefs are the last reminders

during the Nika Riots of 532 when angry crowds at a chariot race nearly overthrew the emperor,

suspended from heaven, light reflecting through its interior. Beneath its grandiose symbolism,
the sturdy reinforcing Corinthian columns, brought from Lebanon after 
the original dome was partially destroyed by an earthquake in 558 CE, quietly remind you of its fragility and the engineering skills
such a marvel requires. If a picture is worth a thousand words, the mosaics from the next several 
centuries have the most to say not only about their Biblical themes, but also the Byzantine emperors who commissioned them, often depicted along with Christ. But beneath their loud and clear voices, one hears the haunting echoes of 
the damaged and missing mosaics and icons, desecrated and looted during 
the Latin Occupation in the Fourth Crusade. Within the floor, the tomb inscription
of Enrico Dandolo, the Venetian ruler who 
commanded the campaign, is a stark reminder of those 57 years that Hagia Sophia spent as a Roman Catholic church before returning to its orthodox roots
upon the Byzantine Reconquest. But it would not remain a church for long. Weakened by the Crusades, Constantinople
fell to the Ottomans in 1453 and would be known as Istanbul thereafter. After allowing his soldiers
three days of pillage, Sultan Mehmed the Second 
entered the building. Though heavily damaged, 
its grandeur was not lost on the young sultan who immediately
rededicated it to Allah, proclaiming that it would be
the new imperial mosque. The four minarets built 
over the next century are the most obvious sign of this era, serving as architectural supports 
in addition to their religious purpose. But there are many others. Ornate candle holders relate 
Suleiman's conquest of Hungary, while giant caligraphy discs 
hung from the ceiling remind visitors for the first 
four caliphs who followed Muhammad. Though the building you see today still
looks like a mosque, it is now a museum, a decision made in 1935 by Kemal Ataturk, the modernizing first president of Turkey following the Ottoman Empire's collapse. It was this secularization
that allowed for removal of the carpets hiding 
the marble floor decorations and the plaster covering 
the Christian mosaics. Ongoing restoration work 
has allowed the multiplicity of voices in Hagia Sophia's long history to be heard again after
centuries of silence. But conflict remains. Hidden mosaics cry out from 
beneath Islamic calligraphy, valuable pieces of history that cannot be
uncovered without destroying others. Meanwhile, calls sound from
both Muslim and Christian communities to return the building to 
its former religious purposes. The story of the divine wisdom 
may be far from over, but one can only hope that 
the many voices residing there will be able to tell their part
for years to come.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Each of the calligraphic disks hung inside of the Hagia Sophia represent ________.
Options: A. Mehmet II’s conquest of the city, B. The beginning of the Ottoman Empire, C. The Qu’ran, D. The rightful caliphs or rulers after the death of Muhammad
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
They say that if walls could talk,
each building would have a story to tell, but few would tell so many fascinating
stories in so many different voices as the Hagia Sophia, or holy wisdom. Perched at the crossroads 
of continents and cultures, it has seen massive changes 
from the name of the city where it stands, to its own structure and purpose. And today, the elements
from each era stand ready to tell their tales 
to any visitor who will listen. Even before you arrive at the Hagia Sophia,
the ancient fortifications hint at the strategic importance 
of the surrounding city, founded as Byzantium 
by Greek colonists in 657 BCE. And successfully renamed as 
Augusta Antonia, New Rome and Constantinople as it was conquered, reconquered,
destroyed and rebuilt by various Greek, Persian and 
Roman rulers over the following centuries. And it was within these walls that 
the first Megale Ekklesia, or great church, was built in the fourth century. Though it was soon burned
to the ground in riots, it established the location for
the region's main religious structure for centuries to come. Near the entrance,
the marble stones with reliefs are the last reminders 
of the second church. Built in 415 CE, it was destroyed 
during the Nika Riots of 532 when angry crowds at a chariot race nearly overthrew the emperor, 
Justinian the First. Having barely managed to retain power, he resolved to rebuild the church
on a grander scale, and five years later, the edifice 
you see before you was completed. As you step inside, the stones 
of the foundation and walls murmur tales from their homelands
of Egypt and Syria, while columns taken from the Temple
of Artemis recall a more ancient past. Runic inscriptions carved by the 
Vikings of the emperor's elite guard carry the lore of distant northern lands. But your attention is caught by 
the grand dome, representing the heavens. Reaching over 50 meters high and 
over 30 meters in diameter and ringed by windows around its base, the golden dome appears
suspended from heaven, light reflecting through its interior. Beneath its grandiose symbolism,
the sturdy reinforcing Corinthian columns, brought from Lebanon after 
the original dome was partially destroyed by an earthquake in 558 CE, quietly remind you of its fragility and the engineering skills
such a marvel requires. If a picture is worth a thousand words, the mosaics from the next several 
centuries have the most to say not only about their Biblical themes, but also the Byzantine emperors who commissioned them, often depicted along with Christ. But beneath their loud and clear voices, one hears the haunting echoes of 
the damaged and missing mosaics and icons, desecrated and looted during 
the Latin Occupation in the Fourth Crusade. Within the floor, the tomb inscription
of Enrico Dandolo, the Venetian ruler who 
commanded the campaign, is a stark reminder of those 57 years that Hagia Sophia spent as a Roman Catholic church before returning to its orthodox roots
upon the Byzantine Reconquest. But it would not remain a church for long. Weakened by the Crusades, Constantinople
fell to the Ottomans in 1453 and would be known as Istanbul thereafter. After allowing his soldiers
three days of pillage, Sultan Mehmed the Second 
entered the building. Though heavily damaged, 
its grandeur was not lost on the young sultan who immediately
rededicated it to Allah, proclaiming that it would be
the new imperial mosque. The four minarets built 
over the next century are the most obvious sign of this era, serving as architectural supports 
in addition to their religious purpose. But there are many others. Ornate candle holders relate 
Suleiman's conquest of Hungary, while giant caligraphy discs 
hung from the ceiling remind visitors for the first 
four caliphs who followed Muhammad. Though the building you see today still
looks like a mosque, it is now a museum, a decision made in 1935 by Kemal Ataturk, the modernizing first president of Turkey following the Ottoman Empire's collapse. It was this secularization
that allowed for removal of the carpets hiding 
the marble floor decorations and the plaster covering 
the Christian mosaics. Ongoing restoration work 
has allowed the multiplicity of voices in Hagia Sophia's long history to be heard again after
centuries of silence. But conflict remains. Hidden mosaics cry out from 
beneath Islamic calligraphy, valuable pieces of history that cannot be
uncovered without destroying others. Meanwhile, calls sound from
both Muslim and Christian communities to return the building to 
its former religious purposes. The story of the divine wisdom 
may be far from over, but one can only hope that 
the many voices residing there will be able to tell their part
for years to come.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Mustafa Kemal became the modernizing president of Turkey and he ________.
Options: A. Established the Hagia Sophia as a Christian Church, as it had been during the time of the Roman conquest, B. Removed the 4 outer minaret towers, C. Allowed for open Islamic worship inside the Hagia Sophia, D. Established the Hagia Sophia as a secular museum
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think about all the things that need to happen for a human settlement to thrive: obtaining food, building shelter, raising children and more. There needs to be a way to divide resources, organize major efforts and distribute labor efficiently. Now imagine having to do this without any sort of planning or higher level communication. Welcome to the ant colony. Ants have some of the most complex social organization in the animal kingdom, living in structured colonies containing different types of members who perform specific roles. But although this may sound similar to some human societies, this organization doesn't arise from any higher level decisions, but is part of a biologically programmed cycle. In many species, all the winged males and winged virgin queens from all the nearby colonies in the population each leave from their different nests and meet at a central place to mate, using pheromones to guide each other to a breeding ground. After mating, the males die off, while females try to establish a new colony. The few that are successful settle down in a suitable spot, lose their wings, and begin laying eggs, selectively fertilizing some using stored sperm they've saved up from mating. Fertilized eggs grow into female workers who care for the queen and her eggs. They will then defend the colony and forage for food, while unfertilized eggs grow into males whose only job is to wait until they are ready to leave the nest and reproduce, beginning the cycle again. So how do worker ants decide what to do and when? Well, they don't really. Although they have no methods of intentional communication, individual ants do interact with one another through touch, sound and chemical signals. These stimuli accomplish many things from serving as an alarm to other ants if one is killed, to signaling when a queen is nearing the end of her reproductive life. But one of the most impressive collective capabilities of an ant colony is to thoroughly and efficiently explore large areas without any predetermined plan. Most species of ants have little or no sense of sight and can only smell things in their vicinity. Combined with their lack of high level coordination, this would seem to make them terrible explorers, but there is an amazingly simple way that ants maximize their searching efficiency; by changing their movement patterns based on individual interactions. When two ants meet, they sense each other by touching antennae. If there are many ants in a small area this will happen more often causing them to respond by moving in more convoluted, random paths in order to search more thoroughly. But in a larger area, with less ants, where such meetings happen less often, they can walk in straight lines to cover more ground. While exploring their environment in this way, an ant may come across any number of things, from threats or enemies, to alternate nesting sites. And some species have another capability known as recruitment. When one of these ants happens to find food, it will return with it, marking its path with a chemical scent. Other ants will then follow this pheromone trail, renewing it each time they manage to find food and return. Once the food in that spot is depleted, the ants stop marking their return. The scent dissipates and ants are no longer attracted to that path. These seemingly crude methods of search and retrieval are, in fact, so useful that they are applied in computer models to obtain optimal solutions from decentralized elements, working randomly and exchanging simple information. This has many theoretical and practical applications, from solving the famous traveling salesman problem, to scheduling computing tasks and optimizing Internet searches, to enabling groups of robots to search a minefield or a burning building collectively, without any central control. But you can observe these fascinatingly simple, yet effective, processes directly through some simple experiments, by allowing ants to enter empty spaces of various sizes and paying attention to their behavior. Ants may not be able to vote, hold meetings or even make any plans, but we humans may still be able to learn something from the way that such simple creatures are able to function so effectively in such complex ways.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who tells an ant what to do?
Options: A. The queen, B. The ant in charge of each task, C. No one, D. The other ants
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is necessary for a human settlement to thrive? Options: A. Obtaining food and building shelter, B. Raising children and distributing labor efficiently, C. Dividing resources, organizing major efforts, and distributing labor efficiently, as well as obtaining food, building shelter, and raising children, D. Higher level communication and planning Correct Option: None
Question 2: How do ants organize their colonies? Options: A. Through higher level decisions and planning, B. Through a biologically programmed cycle, C. Through random movement and interaction, D. Through pheromone signals and intentional communication Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the role of winged males in ant colonies? Options: A. To establish new colonies and lay eggs, B. To mate with winged virgin queens and then die off, C. To forage for food and defend the colony, D. To care for the queen and her eggs Correct Option: None
Question 4: How do worker ants decide what to do and when? Options: A. Through intentional communication and planning, B. Through individual interactions and chemical signals, C. Through random movement and exploration, D. Through pheromone signals and recruitment Correct Option: None
Question 5: How do ants maximize their searching efficiency? Options: A. By moving in straight lines and covering more ground, B. By changing their movement patterns based on individual interactions, C. By using pheromone signals and recruitment, D. By having a predetermined plan and coordinating their efforts Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the purpose of pheromone trails in ant colonies? Options: A. To mark the path to food and recruit other ants, B. To signal when a queen is nearing the end of her reproductive life, C. To serve as an alarm to other ants if one is killed, D. To coordinate the movement of ants and optimize their searching efficiency Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the "traveling salesman problem"? Options: A. A problem in computer science that involves finding the shortest path between two points, B. A problem in biology that involves understanding how ants navigate their environment, C. A problem in mathematics that involves finding the optimal solution to a complex problem, D. A problem in engineering that involves designing more efficient systems Correct Option: None
Question 8: How are ant colonies able to function effectively without central control? Options: A. Through the use of pheromone signals and recruitment, B. Through the use of simple rules and individual interactions, C. Through the use of complex algorithms and planning, D. Through the use of decentralized elements and random movement Correct Option: None
Question 9: What can humans learn from the way ants function? Options: A. The importance of central control and planning, B. The importance of individual interactions and simple rules, C. The importance of pheromone signals and recruitment, D. The importance of complex algorithms and optimization Correct Option: None
Question 10: How can the behavior of ants be observed and studied? Options: A. Through simple experiments and observation, B. Through complex algorithms and simulation, C. Through the use of pheromone signals and recruitment, D. Through the study of ant colonies in their natural habitat Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4: How do worker ants decide what to do and when? 

Although the options do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ, the intent and content of the question are similar. The ground truth MCQ asks "Who tells an ant what to do?" and the correct answer is "No one", implying that ants do not receive direct instructions. Similarly, Question 4 asks "How do worker ants decide what to do and when?" and the correct answer would be related to individual interactions and chemical signals, implying that ants do not receive direct instructions but instead make decisions based on their interactions and environment.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Think about all the things that need to happen for a human settlement to thrive: obtaining food, building shelter, raising children and more. There needs to be a way to divide resources, organize major efforts and distribute labor efficiently. Now imagine having to do this without any sort of planning or higher level communication. Welcome to the ant colony. Ants have some of the most complex social organization in the animal kingdom, living in structured colonies containing different types of members who perform specific roles. But although this may sound similar to some human societies, this organization doesn't arise from any higher level decisions, but is part of a biologically programmed cycle. In many species, all the winged males and winged virgin queens from all the nearby colonies in the population each leave from their different nests and meet at a central place to mate, using pheromones to guide each other to a breeding ground. After mating, the males die off, while females try to establish a new colony. The few that are successful settle down in a suitable spot, lose their wings, and begin laying eggs, selectively fertilizing some using stored sperm they've saved up from mating. Fertilized eggs grow into female workers who care for the queen and her eggs. They will then defend the colony and forage for food, while unfertilized eggs grow into males whose only job is to wait until they are ready to leave the nest and reproduce, beginning the cycle again. So how do worker ants decide what to do and when? Well, they don't really. Although they have no methods of intentional communication, individual ants do interact with one another through touch, sound and chemical signals. These stimuli accomplish many things from serving as an alarm to other ants if one is killed, to signaling when a queen is nearing the end of her reproductive life. But one of the most impressive collective capabilities of an ant colony is to thoroughly and efficiently explore large areas without any predetermined plan. Most species of ants have little or no sense of sight and can only smell things in their vicinity. Combined with their lack of high level coordination, this would seem to make them terrible explorers, but there is an amazingly simple way that ants maximize their searching efficiency; by changing their movement patterns based on individual interactions. When two ants meet, they sense each other by touching antennae. If there are many ants in a small area this will happen more often causing them to respond by moving in more convoluted, random paths in order to search more thoroughly. But in a larger area, with less ants, where such meetings happen less often, they can walk in straight lines to cover more ground. While exploring their environment in this way, an ant may come across any number of things, from threats or enemies, to alternate nesting sites. And some species have another capability known as recruitment. When one of these ants happens to find food, it will return with it, marking its path with a chemical scent. Other ants will then follow this pheromone trail, renewing it each time they manage to find food and return. Once the food in that spot is depleted, the ants stop marking their return. The scent dissipates and ants are no longer attracted to that path. These seemingly crude methods of search and retrieval are, in fact, so useful that they are applied in computer models to obtain optimal solutions from decentralized elements, working randomly and exchanging simple information. This has many theoretical and practical applications, from solving the famous traveling salesman problem, to scheduling computing tasks and optimizing Internet searches, to enabling groups of robots to search a minefield or a burning building collectively, without any central control. But you can observe these fascinatingly simple, yet effective, processes directly through some simple experiments, by allowing ants to enter empty spaces of various sizes and paying attention to their behavior. Ants may not be able to vote, hold meetings or even make any plans, but we humans may still be able to learn something from the way that such simple creatures are able to function so effectively in such complex ways.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How should ants move to cover as much area as possible when they are searching?
Options: A. In paths shaped like a squiggly line, B. In straight lines, C. In steps, D. Doesn’t matter
Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
Think about all the things that need to happen for a human settlement to thrive: obtaining food, building shelter, raising children and more. There needs to be a way to divide resources, organize major efforts and distribute labor efficiently. Now imagine having to do this without any sort of planning or higher level communication. Welcome to the ant colony. Ants have some of the most complex social organization in the animal kingdom, living in structured colonies containing different types of members who perform specific roles. But although this may sound similar to some human societies, this organization doesn't arise from any higher level decisions, but is part of a biologically programmed cycle. In many species, all the winged males and winged virgin queens from all the nearby colonies in the population each leave from their different nests and meet at a central place to mate, using pheromones to guide each other to a breeding ground. After mating, the males die off, while females try to establish a new colony. The few that are successful settle down in a suitable spot, lose their wings, and begin laying eggs, selectively fertilizing some using stored sperm they've saved up from mating. Fertilized eggs grow into female workers who care for the queen and her eggs. They will then defend the colony and forage for food, while unfertilized eggs grow into males whose only job is to wait until they are ready to leave the nest and reproduce, beginning the cycle again. So how do worker ants decide what to do and when? Well, they don't really. Although they have no methods of intentional communication, individual ants do interact with one another through touch, sound and chemical signals. These stimuli accomplish many things from serving as an alarm to other ants if one is killed, to signaling when a queen is nearing the end of her reproductive life. But one of the most impressive collective capabilities of an ant colony is to thoroughly and efficiently explore large areas without any predetermined plan. Most species of ants have little or no sense of sight and can only smell things in their vicinity. Combined with their lack of high level coordination, this would seem to make them terrible explorers, but there is an amazingly simple way that ants maximize their searching efficiency; by changing their movement patterns based on individual interactions. When two ants meet, they sense each other by touching antennae. If there are many ants in a small area this will happen more often causing them to respond by moving in more convoluted, random paths in order to search more thoroughly. But in a larger area, with less ants, where such meetings happen less often, they can walk in straight lines to cover more ground. While exploring their environment in this way, an ant may come across any number of things, from threats or enemies, to alternate nesting sites. And some species have another capability known as recruitment. When one of these ants happens to find food, it will return with it, marking its path with a chemical scent. Other ants will then follow this pheromone trail, renewing it each time they manage to find food and return. Once the food in that spot is depleted, the ants stop marking their return. The scent dissipates and ants are no longer attracted to that path. These seemingly crude methods of search and retrieval are, in fact, so useful that they are applied in computer models to obtain optimal solutions from decentralized elements, working randomly and exchanging simple information. This has many theoretical and practical applications, from solving the famous traveling salesman problem, to scheduling computing tasks and optimizing Internet searches, to enabling groups of robots to search a minefield or a burning building collectively, without any central control. But you can observe these fascinatingly simple, yet effective, processes directly through some simple experiments, by allowing ants to enter empty spaces of various sizes and paying attention to their behavior. Ants may not be able to vote, hold meetings or even make any plans, but we humans may still be able to learn something from the way that such simple creatures are able to function so effectively in such complex ways.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Jessica Ruby
Reviewer: Caroline Cristal You may not realize it, but from the moment you got out of bed today to the point where you sat down to watch this video, you've essentially been swimming. Why? Because air is a fluid just like water. It has waves and eddies. It flows. And when you push air out of the way, it rushes around you into a wake. So why don't we notice it most of the time? We commonly think of air as empty space. But while one cubic centimeter of interstellar space, the volume in the tip of your pinky finger, contains roughly one atom, the same volume of air has about 10 quintillion molecules. If that sounds hard to wrap your head around, it happens to be about the same as the number of insects alive on the planet, all crawling, climbing, and flying over each other in an enormous, tightly packed swarm. When this swarm of molecules runs into things, it exerts a force, pressing against the boundaries of the fluid, like water pressing against the glass of a bottle. This is known as air pressure. And while air is lighter than water, all those molecules still get pretty heavy, with the total air filling a typical school gym, weighing about as much as an adult elephant. So when you walk into a gym, how come you're not immediately crushed by the elephant of air in the room? Well, first of all, because most of it is pressing on the floor and the walls, and the part that is pressing on you is pushed back by the pressure inside you! You see, the air, as well as the water and everything else, that fills our bodies exerts an amount of pressure equal to that of the air outside. Of course, this is no accident. It's precisely what allows us to survive in the normal atmosphere, and what makes it more difficult at high altitudes or deep water. And we normally don't feel the air pressing on us because it's generally uniform. So even though different amounts of air molecules are hitting you at different times, the swarm is so thick that all those little differences average out. What happens when air pressure isn't uniform? This means that the molecules are pushing harder in one region of air than another, driving the air flow from the higher pressure region to the lower. We feel this flow directly as wind, and the pressure systems that meteorologists are always going on about are responsible for other weather changes, from the mundane to the catastrophic. But differences in air pressure do more than just let us complain about the weather; they're the very reason we're alive. We breathe by lowering the pressure in our lungs, allowing air to rush in. So the next time you take a deep breath, think of the unfathomable number of air molecules you're commanding to move. We look up at the night sky to ponder the infinity of space, but unless you're watching this video from that deep space, there are more air molecules in and around your body than there are grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts, stars in the visible universe, or both of those numbers combined. The vastness of the universe is right in front of you and inside you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The air in a typical gymnasium can weigh as much as ________.
Options: A. A brick, B. A bicycle, C. An elephant, D. A blue whale
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason we don't notice the fluidity of air most of the time? Options: A. Because air is too light to exert a significant force., B. Because air is too thin to be noticeable., C. Because we commonly think of air as empty space., D. Because air is too dense to be felt. Correct Option: None
Question 2: How many molecules of air are present in a cubic centimeter of air? Options: A. About 1 molecule, B. About 100 molecules, C. About 10 quintillion molecules, D. About 100 quintillion molecules Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the force exerted by the swarm of air molecules when it runs into things? Options: A. Gravity, B. Friction, C. Air pressure, D. Electromagnetic force Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why are we not immediately crushed by the weight of air in a room? Options: A. Because the air is too light to exert a significant force., B. Because most of the air is pressing on the floor and walls, and the part that is pressing on us is pushed back by the pressure inside us., C. Because the air is too thin to be noticeable., D. Because we are too dense to be affected by air pressure. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens when air pressure isn't uniform? Options: A. The air molecules stop moving., B. The air flow becomes stagnant., C. The molecules push harder in one region of air than another, driving the air flow from the higher pressure region to the lower., D. The air pressure becomes zero. Correct Option: None
Question 6: How do we breathe? Options: A. By increasing the pressure in our lungs., B. By decreasing the pressure in our lungs., C. By holding our breath., D. By exhaling slowly. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the result of differences in air pressure? Options: A. The air flow becomes stagnant., B. The air pressure becomes zero., C. Wind and weather changes occur., D. The air molecules stop moving. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How many air molecules are present in and around the human body? Options: A. More than the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., B. Less than the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., C. Equal to the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., D. Unknown. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the reason for the vastness of the universe being right in front of us and inside us? Options: A. Because of the number of stars in the visible universe., B. Because of the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., C. Because of the number of air molecules present in and around the human body., D. Because of the size of the universe. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the effect of air pressure on the human body at high altitudes or deep water? Options: A. It becomes easier to breathe., B. It becomes more difficult to breathe., C. It has no effect on breathing., D. It causes the body to expand. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Transcriber: Jessica Ruby
Reviewer: Caroline Cristal You may not realize it, but from the moment you got out of bed today to the point where you sat down to watch this video, you've essentially been swimming. Why? Because air is a fluid just like water. It has waves and eddies. It flows. And when you push air out of the way, it rushes around you into a wake. So why don't we notice it most of the time? We commonly think of air as empty space. But while one cubic centimeter of interstellar space, the volume in the tip of your pinky finger, contains roughly one atom, the same volume of air has about 10 quintillion molecules. If that sounds hard to wrap your head around, it happens to be about the same as the number of insects alive on the planet, all crawling, climbing, and flying over each other in an enormous, tightly packed swarm. When this swarm of molecules runs into things, it exerts a force, pressing against the boundaries of the fluid, like water pressing against the glass of a bottle. This is known as air pressure. And while air is lighter than water, all those molecules still get pretty heavy, with the total air filling a typical school gym, weighing about as much as an adult elephant. So when you walk into a gym, how come you're not immediately crushed by the elephant of air in the room? Well, first of all, because most of it is pressing on the floor and the walls, and the part that is pressing on you is pushed back by the pressure inside you! You see, the air, as well as the water and everything else, that fills our bodies exerts an amount of pressure equal to that of the air outside. Of course, this is no accident. It's precisely what allows us to survive in the normal atmosphere, and what makes it more difficult at high altitudes or deep water. And we normally don't feel the air pressing on us because it's generally uniform. So even though different amounts of air molecules are hitting you at different times, the swarm is so thick that all those little differences average out. What happens when air pressure isn't uniform? This means that the molecules are pushing harder in one region of air than another, driving the air flow from the higher pressure region to the lower. We feel this flow directly as wind, and the pressure systems that meteorologists are always going on about are responsible for other weather changes, from the mundane to the catastrophic. But differences in air pressure do more than just let us complain about the weather; they're the very reason we're alive. We breathe by lowering the pressure in our lungs, allowing air to rush in. So the next time you take a deep breath, think of the unfathomable number of air molecules you're commanding to move. We look up at the night sky to ponder the infinity of space, but unless you're watching this video from that deep space, there are more air molecules in and around your body than there are grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts, stars in the visible universe, or both of those numbers combined. The vastness of the universe is right in front of you and inside you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following flows is NOT driven by pressure differences?
Options: A. A deep breath, B. A river, C. A gust of wind, D. A sip through a drinking straw
Correct Option: B

Because we are too dense to be affected by air pressure. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens when air pressure isn't uniform? Options: A. The air molecules stop moving., B. The air flow becomes stagnant., C. The molecules push harder in one region of air than another, driving the air flow from the higher pressure region to the lower., D. The air pressure becomes zero. Correct Option: None
Question 6: How do we breathe? Options: A. By increasing the pressure in our lungs., B. By decreasing the pressure in our lungs., C. By holding our breath., D. By exhaling slowly. Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the result of differences in air pressure? Options: A. The air flow becomes stagnant., B. The air pressure becomes zero., C. Wind and weather changes occur., D. The air molecules stop moving. Correct Option: None
Question 8: How many air molecules are present in and around the human body? Options: A. More than the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., B. Less than the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., C. Equal to the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., D. Unknown. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the reason for the vastness of the universe being right in front of us and inside us? Options: A. Because of the number of stars in the visible universe., B. Because of the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., C. Because of the number of air molecules present in and around the human body., D. Because of the size of the universe. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the effect of air pressure on the human body at high altitudes or deep water? Options: A. It becomes easier to breathe., B. It becomes more difficult to breathe., C. It has no effect on breathing., D. It causes the body to expand. Correct Option: None

Less than the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., C. Equal to the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., D. Unknown. Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the reason for the vastness of the universe being right in front of us and inside us? Options: A. Because of the number of stars in the visible universe., B. Because of the number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts., C. Because of the number of air molecules present in and around the human body., D. Because of the size of the universe. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the effect of air pressure on the human body at high altitudes or deep water? Options: A. It becomes easier to breathe., B. It becomes more difficult to breathe., C. It has no effect on breathing., D. It causes the body to expand. Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Living with her family high
above the ground in the northern tropical forests
of Colombia, you will find Shakira, a cotton-top tamarin with a penchant
for conversation. Say, "Hola!" Though you may not realize it, this one pound monkey communicates in a highly sophisticated language of 38 distinct calls based on variations of chirps
and whistles. The response she just gave is known as a "B chirp", a call often directed at humans. To appreciate the complexities
of Shakira’s language, let's learn a few chirps and whistles, then examine how their combinations form grammatically structured sequences. The chirp Shakira used to greet us comes from a class of calls known as single frequency modulated syllables. This class is made up of short
duration calls, or chirps, and long duration calls,
like screams and squeals. Researchers have determined that there
are eight different types of chirps categorized by stem upsweep, duration,
peak frequency, and frequency change. In addition, each chirp has
its own unique meaning. For example, Shakira’s “C chirp” is used when she is approaching food, where as her “D chirp” is only used when she has
the food in hand. Single whistles also exhibit
a unique intention with each call and just as there are
eight different chirps, there are five different whistles. Based on frequency modulation, single whistles are subdivided
into four categories: squeaks, initially modulated whistles, terminally modulated whistles, and flat whistles. The language's quality of unique intention is wonderfully exemplified by the category of initially modulated whistles. These whistles change based
on the proximity of Shakira to other members of her family. If Shakira is greater than 0.6 meters
from her family, she’ll sound a large
initally modulated whistle. But if she’s less than 0.6 meters
from her family, she’ll sound a small
initially modulated whistle. Now that we’ve learned a few
chirps and whistles, Shakira wants to show off by taking you through a quick day in her life
with these calls. While heading towards a feeding tree
for her first meal of the day, she says: “(monkey noise)“, a call most often used
in relaxed investigations. However, suddenly she spots
the shadow of a hawk. "E chirp" for alarm. This call alerts her family
to the presence of this predator, and Shakira jumps to the safety
of an inner branch. The coast seems clear, so Shakira makes her way towards her dad. Wait, wait. Who is that? Ah, it's her younger brother, Carlos. Cotton-top tamarins often squeal
during play wrestling. Uh-oh. He’s playing a little too roughly,
and Shakira screams, alerting her parents to help her. Her dad makes his way
towards the ball of rolling fur and her brother stops. Shakira shakes herself and scratches herself to get the hair
on her head back in place. Then Shakira spots another group
of unfamiliar tamarins and hears their normal long call. She turns to her family. Did you catch that? First there was a chirp,
and then a whistle. This is what’s known as
a combination vocalization, a phrase that contains
both a chirp and a whistle. These are two calls strung together
to convey a message. The combination of these two elements alerts her family to the presence
of another group, the “F chirp”, and the distance
they are away, the normal long call whistle. In other words,
Shakira just said a sentence. Her simple demonstration
is just the tip of the iceberg. She’s got trills, chatters,
multiple whistle calls, more combination vocalizations,
even twitters. Yet sadly enough, we may not get to hear everything she has to say. Mixed in with chirping sonatas
from high above is the constant thud of a machete
chopping trees. Shakira’s habitat in Colombia
is being cut down, piece by piece, and if we don't work to protect the critically endangered
cotton-top tamarin, it will become extinct in our lifetime. If the chirp from one tamarin to the next has proven to be more
than just idle chit chat, imagine what else we have left
to discover. Imagine what else Shakira can tell us.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cotton-top tamarins can communicate using ________.
Options: A. Chirps, B. Whistles, C. Combinations of chirps and whistles, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of animal is Shakira, and where does she live? Options: A. Shakira is a monkey who lives in the southern tropical forests of Brazil., B. Shakira is a monkey who lives in the northern tropical forests of Colombia., C. Shakira is a bird who lives in the southern tropical forests of Argentina., D. Shakira is a bird who lives in the northern tropical forests of Peru. Correct Option: None
Question 2: How many distinct calls are in Shakira's language, and what are they based on? Options: A. 20 distinct calls based on variations of barks and roars., B. 38 distinct calls based on variations of chirps and whistles., C. 50 distinct calls based on variations of screams and squeals., D. 100 distinct calls based on variations of trills and chatters. Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the call that Shakira uses to greet humans, and what type of call is it? Options: A. The call is known as a "C chirp", and it is a long-duration call., B. The call is known as a "B chirp", and it is a short-duration call., C. The call is known as a "D chirp", and it is a high-frequency call., D. The call is known as an "E chirp", and it is a low-frequency call. Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the difference between Shakira's "C chirp" and "D chirp"? Options: A. The "C chirp" is used when Shakira is approaching food, while the "D chirp" is used when she has the food in hand., B. The "C chirp" is used when Shakira is playing, while the "D chirp" is used when she is resting., C. The "C chirp" is used when Shakira is alarmed, while the "D chirp" is used when she is relaxed., D. The "C chirp" is used when Shakira is with her family, while the "D chirp" is used when she is alone. Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the purpose of Shakira's initially modulated whistles, and how do they change? Options: A. The whistles are used to alert Shakira's family to the presence of a predator, and they change based on the proximity of the predator., B. The whistles are used to communicate with other tamarins, and they change based on the distance between Shakira and the other tamarins., C. The whistles are used to signal Shakira's location to her family, and they change based on Shakira's proximity to her family., D. The whistles are used to initiate play, and they change based on the type of play. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a combination vocalization in Shakira's language, and what does it convey? Options: A. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains two chirps, and it conveys a message about food., B. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains a chirp and a whistle, and it conveys a message about the presence of another group., C. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains two whistles, and it conveys a message about danger., D. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains a chirp and a scream, and it conveys a message about excitement. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why is Shakira's habitat in Colombia being threatened, and what could happen to the cotton-top tamarin as a result? Options: A. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by climate change, and the cotton-top tamarin could become extinct as a result., B. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by deforestation, and the cotton-top tamarin could become extinct as a result., C. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by pollution, and the cotton-top tamarin could become endangered as a result., D. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by hunting, and the cotton-top tamarin could become vulnerable as a result. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is unique about the cotton-top tamarin's language, and what can it tell us? Options: A. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a complex system of chirps and whistles, and it can tell us about the tamarin's social behavior., B. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a simple system of barks and roars, and it can tell us about the tamarin's habitat., C. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a combination of vocalizations and body language, and it can tell us about the tamarin's emotions., D. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a sophisticated system of trills and chatters, and it can tell us about the tamarin's intelligence. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do Shakira's vocalizations change when she is approaching food versus when she has food in hand? Options: A. Shakira uses a "C chirp" when approaching food and a "D chirp" when she has food in hand., B. Shakira uses a "D chirp" when approaching food and a "C chirp" when she has food in hand., C. Shakira uses a "B chirp" when approaching food and an "E chirp" when she has food in hand., D. Shakira uses an "E chirp" when approaching food and a "B chirp" when she has food in hand. Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the significance of Shakira's language, and what can it reveal about the cotton-top tamarin? Options: A. Shakira's language is significant because it reveals the cotton-top tamarin's ability to communicate complex information, and it can tell us about the tamarin's social behavior and intelligence., B. Shakira's language is significant because it reveals the cotton-top tamarin's ability to mimic human speech, and it can tell us about the tamarin's cognitive abilities., C. Shakira's language is significant because it reveals the cotton-top tamarin's ability to express emotions, and it can tell us about the tamarin's emotional intelligence., D. Shakira's language is significant because it reveals the cotton-top tamarin's ability to learn and adapt, and it can tell us about the tamarin's adaptability. Correct Option: None

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Transcript**:
Living with her family high
above the ground in the northern tropical forests
of Colombia, you will find Shakira, a cotton-top tamarin with a penchant
for conversation. Say, "Hola!" Though you may not realize it, this one pound monkey communicates in a highly sophisticated language of 38 distinct calls based on variations of chirps
and whistles. The response she just gave is known as a "B chirp", a call often directed at humans. To appreciate the complexities
of Shakira’s language, let's learn a few chirps and whistles, then examine how their combinations form grammatically structured sequences. The chirp Shakira used to greet us comes from a class of calls known as single frequency modulated syllables. This class is made up of short
duration calls, or chirps, and long duration calls,
like screams and squeals. Researchers have determined that there
are eight different types of chirps categorized by stem upsweep, duration,
peak frequency, and frequency change. In addition, each chirp has
its own unique meaning. For example, Shakira’s “C chirp” is used when she is approaching food, where as her “D chirp” is only used when she has
the food in hand. Single whistles also exhibit
a unique intention with each call and just as there are
eight different chirps, there are five different whistles. Based on frequency modulation, single whistles are subdivided
into four categories: squeaks, initially modulated whistles, terminally modulated whistles, and flat whistles. The language's quality of unique intention is wonderfully exemplified by the category of initially modulated whistles. These whistles change based
on the proximity of Shakira to other members of her family. If Shakira is greater than 0.6 meters
from her family, she’ll sound a large
initally modulated whistle. But if she’s less than 0.6 meters
from her family, she’ll sound a small
initially modulated whistle. Now that we’ve learned a few
chirps and whistles, Shakira wants to show off by taking you through a quick day in her life
with these calls. While heading towards a feeding tree
for her first meal of the day, she says: “(monkey noise)“, a call most often used
in relaxed investigations. However, suddenly she spots
the shadow of a hawk. "E chirp" for alarm. This call alerts her family
to the presence of this predator, and Shakira jumps to the safety
of an inner branch. The coast seems clear, so Shakira makes her way towards her dad. Wait, wait. Who is that? Ah, it's her younger brother, Carlos. Cotton-top tamarins often squeal
during play wrestling. Uh-oh. He’s playing a little too roughly,
and Shakira screams, alerting her parents to help her. Her dad makes his way
towards the ball of rolling fur and her brother stops. Shakira shakes herself and scratches herself to get the hair
on her head back in place. Then Shakira spots another group
of unfamiliar tamarins and hears their normal long call. She turns to her family. Did you catch that? First there was a chirp,
and then a whistle. This is what’s known as
a combination vocalization, a phrase that contains
both a chirp and a whistle. These are two calls strung together
to convey a message. The combination of these two elements alerts her family to the presence
of another group, the “F chirp”, and the distance
they are away, the normal long call whistle. In other words,
Shakira just said a sentence. Her simple demonstration
is just the tip of the iceberg. She’s got trills, chatters,
multiple whistle calls, more combination vocalizations,
even twitters. Yet sadly enough, we may not get to hear everything she has to say. Mixed in with chirping sonatas
from high above is the constant thud of a machete
chopping trees. Shakira’s habitat in Colombia
is being cut down, piece by piece, and if we don't work to protect the critically endangered
cotton-top tamarin, it will become extinct in our lifetime. If the chirp from one tamarin to the next has proven to be more
than just idle chit chat, imagine what else we have left
to discover. Imagine what else Shakira can tell us.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cotton-top tamarins can construct “sentences” ________.
Options: A. Using different types of whistles, B. Combining chirps and whistles, C. Combining a variety of chirps
Correct Option: B

The whistles are used to signal Shakira's location to her family, and they change based on Shakira's proximity to her family., D. The whistles are used to initiate play, and they change based on the type of play. Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is a combination vocalization in Shakira's language, and what does it convey? Options: A. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains two chirps, and it conveys a message about food., B. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains a chirp and a whistle, and it conveys a message about the presence of another group., C. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains two whistles, and it conveys a message about danger., D. A combination vocalization is a phrase that contains a chirp and a scream, and it conveys a message about excitement. Correct Option: None
Question 7: Why is Shakira's habitat in Colombia being threatened, and what could happen to the cotton-top tamarin as a result? Options: A. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by climate change, and the cotton-top tamarin could become extinct as a result., B. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by deforestation, and the cotton-top tamarin could become extinct as a result., C. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by pollution, and the cotton-top tamarin could become endangered as a result., D. Shakira's habitat is being threatened by hunting, and the cotton-top tamarin could become vulnerable as a result. Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is unique about the cotton-top tamarin's language, and what can it tell us? Options: A. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a complex system of chirps and whistles, and it can tell us about the tamarin's social behavior., B. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a simple system of barks and roars, and it can tell us about the tamarin's habitat., C. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a combination of vocalizations and body language, and it can tell us about the tamarin's emotions., D. The cotton-top tamarin's language is unique because it is based on a sophisticated system of trills and chatters, and it can tell us about the tamarin's intelligence. Correct Option: None
Question 9: How do Shakira's vocalizations change when she is approaching food versus when she has food in hand? Options: A. Shakira uses a "C chirp" when approaching food and a "D chirp" when she has food in hand., B. Shakira uses a "D chirp" when approaching food and a "C chirp" when she has food in hand., C. Shakira uses a "B chirp" when approaching food and an "E chirp" when she has food in hand., D. Shakira uses an "E chirp" when approaching food and a "B chirp" when she has food in hand. Correct Option: None

Shakira's language is significant because it reveals the cotton-top tamarin's ability to mimic human speech, and it can tell us about the tamarin's cognitive abilities., C. Shakira's language is significant because it reveals the cotton-top tamarin's ability to express emotions, and it can tell us about the tamarin's emotional intelligence., D.
